Let $f(n)$ count the number of sum-free $A\subseteq \{1,\ldots,n\}$, i.e. $A$ contains no solutions to $a=b+c$ with $a,b,c\in A$. Is it true that\[f(n)=2^{(1+o(1))\frac{n}{2}}?\]



The Cameron-Erd\H{os conjecture}. It is trivial to see that $f(n) \geq 2^{\frac{n}{2}}$, considering all subsets of $[n/2,n]$.

This is true, and in fact $f(n) \ll 2^{n/2}$, which was proved independently by Green \cite{Gr04} and Sapozhenko \cite{Sa03}. In fact, both papers prove the stronger asymptotic $f(n) \sim c_n 2^{n/2}$, where $c_n$ takes on one of two values depending on the parity of $n$.

See [877] for the maximal case.




References


[Gr04] Green, Ben, The Cameron-Erd\H{o}s conjecture. Bull. London Math. Soc. (2004), 769-778.

[Sa03] Sapozhenko, A. A., The Cameron-Erd\H{o}s conjecture. Dokl. Akad. Nauk (2003), 749-752.
